you
we're just about to land in the most
reclusive country on this planet North
Korea with 23 billion citizens and a
very controlling totality Aryan regime
this is one of the few links between the
outside world and North Korea the flight
from Beijing to Pyongyang that regime
wants some things you want to tourists
in and the hard currency they bring for
an impoverished economy what it doesn't
want though is full outside information
it is a much more complicated place than
is sometimes presented to the outside
world so let's go and see what it's like
the first thing you notice is an
ultra-modern state-of-the-art airport
the regime has spent an awful lot of
money on this Airport but the big
question is is it simply too big for the
demand 30,000 tourists come in every
year from China far fewer from the West
if they want more tourists they may have
to open up and opening up represent
danger for the regime
[Music]
this is the bus from the airport to the
center of Pyongyang we're going through
a very built-up area it's well after six
o'clock and evening well into dusk
darkness has fallen but what you'll
notice is that we're passing blocks of
flats apartment blocks with virtually no
light coming out of them
odd glimmers of light in some of them
this is not a country not an economy
where electricity is abundant where it
does seem to be abundant is where you
see effigies and statues of the leaders
of Kim il-sung and his son Kim jong-il
[Music]
this is the Pompeian underground not
many people get to see this kind of view
these are commuters they look pretty
well like commuters everywhere rushing
to work in this case rushing towards
work not coming off there's another
train just arriving over there of course
it is in a way a commute like everywhere
else but this country is a very
different country these people are very
close physically but it feels like a
million miles away sometimes you get
very warming bits of human contact you
look through the windows there and you
see a child and that child will just
wave at you it's that human contact
across a political divide which is rare
for the most part people are very cagey
I suppose about the Western media the
station I think is pretty amazing built
in the early 1970s
it's called glory one step up there one
stop up there rather is
and once knock down that way is torch if
you look at the pillars they are a torch
and that torch is a symbol of the North
Korea ideology it's about self-reliance
it's very important in this country and
if you look right at the end of the
corridor there you see the Dear Leader
looking down on the whole station they
follow the news avidly and those who
would talk to us were full square behind
the leadership Jesus once again people
see Jesus he says he hopes BBC news
reports the parade so that the people of
the world know how we celebrate this
glorious day
[Music]
the tremulous old stadium in Pyongyang a
pretty amazing spectacle the DPRK North
Korea against the Philippines a
qualifying match for the World Cup in
Moscow the home support is the whole of
that far banking in the red the white
and the blue and I've never seen
football support like a very organized
very regimented football support
regimented and orchestrated by the
middle of the bottom run there the home
support has a conductor who organizes
the chanting within ripples as one
through that far side a very very
different football experience and a very
regimented organized society the game is
over nil nil if you want to know the
score only a game though all these
people now sweeping out into the real
world of the DPRK North Korea it is a
changing world as outside influence
comes but one thing doesn't change the
regimentation and the total control from
the top nobody knows how long that total
control will survive
not even the supreme leader himself Kim
jong-un
